instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.P3V3S0_EN: What is P3V3S0_EN? This signal enables the PP3V3_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't power on
threads.message:
Hi,

Another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.

Solid green light after 4-5sec goes to orange.
Customer said it was liquid damaged.
Only corrosion was around the JTAG connector.
I thought this gonna be an easy fix, but of course no.

Measurements:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.57V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> - 1.05V

<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>
Pin 1 3.42V
Pin 12 nice wave form 32KHz

Checked <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR>/3 and everything looks fine.

SMC crystal does not oscillate and no voltage on it.
Some with Y1905.

<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> - 1.9V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> - 0V

What am I missing?

Thank you.

Edit: It was in the Ultra sonic cleaner too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't power on
threads.message: Did you remove the connector? Did you check the usually resistors in serie with <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> data lines, <RESISTOR>R6110</RESISTOR>-31?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't power on
threads.message:
Yes, I did remove the connector.

I checked all the resistors in series on page 46. I can't find <RESISTOR>R6131</RESISTOR>.

I tried different BIOS too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't power on
threads.message: No idea, check traces to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and resistors for corrosion. Is there a pulse on L7520 when connecting power.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't power on
threads.message:
When I checked the resistors I checked the traces to the EFI chip.

Yes, there is some pulse on L7520 when I connect the adapter.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't power on
threads.message: Is there a pulse on other rails too? CPU Vcore also coming high for a moment?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't power on
threads.message:
There is no pulse on CPU Vcore.
However there is a weird looking 2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>. No pulse but 2V continuously.
Also I've 0.9V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS_FET_R</SIGNAL>.
L7430 comes on for a sec.


I checked <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> and the <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL> is missing so I don't know how that is possible to have 2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>.
But looks like <CHIP>U8050</CHIP> is burned. Could that be the problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> doesn't power on
threads.message: If <CHIP>U8050</CHIP> is really fried then you should replace it. Check for a short on <RESISTOR>R8050</RESISTOR> to GND first though.
